metadata.case_name: Associated Industries (P) Ltd. v. Regional Provident Fund Commissioner

facts.text: The appellant is a company which runs a tile factory started in July 1943 and an engineering works started in September 1950 at Quilon.
The tile factory and engineering works are separate and distinct industries carried on by the same company on the same premises.
A single licence under the Factories Act, 1948 has been issued for the entire premises, allowing it to be used as one factory.
Respondent intimated appellant on March 10, 1953 that the Act and scheme apply to appellant's factory and required deposit of contributions and charges under s.6.
Requisition repeated on March 25, 1953 and April 24, 1953.
Appellant disputed applicability and refused to comply.
Respondent informed appellant on June 16, 1953 that appropriate action would be taken for non-compliance.
Appellant filed writ petition O.P. No. 97/1953 in Kerala High Court seeking certiorari to quash notices and restrain respondent.
Kerala High Court dismissed the writ petition on August 8, 1960 with costs.
Engineering industry employs 24 workers, tiles industry employs more than 50.
Respondent conceded not to collect employees' share of contribution for relevant period from appellant.
Subsequent to High Court decision, tiles industry included in Sch. I.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant's factory falls within s.1(3) of the Employees Provident Funds Act, 1952.
Whether the notices served by respondent were retrospective and illegal.
Whether enforcing notices would be inequitable since employees had not made contributions.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant's factory is not an establishment to which s.1(3) applies as it runs two separate industries, tiles not in Sch. I.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.1(3), Sch. I of Employees Provident Funds Act, 1952

petitioner_arguments.text: Tiles industry is primary and dominant (started first, more employees), engineering subsidiary, so factory outside s.1(3).
Inequitable to enforce as employees had not contributed.
Distinction should be made between industries for contribution rates post-1962 amendment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.6 as amended by Act 48 of 1962

respondent_arguments.text: Act and scheme applicable to appellant's factory.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.1(3) of Employees Provident Funds Act, 1952

respondent_arguments.text: Will not collect employees' share for relevant period from appellant.

court_reasoning.text: Principal issue concluded by Regional Provident Fund Commr. v. Shree Krishna Metal Mfg. Co.: s.1(3)(a) not confined to factories exclusively engaged in Sch. I industry; applies to composite factories engaged in any Sch. I industry with 50+ employees.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Factory engaged in any industry in Sch. I with requisite employees falls under s.1(3)(a), including composite factories.

court_reasoning.text: Tile and engineering industries are independent and distinct, not one primary with other subsidiary; thus factory falls under s.1(3)(a).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Where industries independent, no inquiry into dominant vs. subsidiary; applies if one falls under Sch. I.

court_reasoning.text: Rejected argument on retrospectivity and inequity based on respondent's concession on employees' share.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court correctly rejected these contentions.

court_reasoning.text: Declined to decide hypothetical issue on differential contribution rates.

holdings.text: Appellant's factory falls within s.1(3) of the Act as a composite factory running independent industries, one (engineering) in Sch. I with sufficient employees.

precedents_cited.case_name: Regional Provident Fund Commissioner, Bombay v. Shree Krishna Metal Manufacturing Co., Bhandra and Oudh Sugar Mills Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Holds s.1(3)(a) applies to composite factories engaged in any Sch. I industry; numerical test to factory, not industry; distinguishes independent vs. subsidiary activities.

statutes_cited.name: Employees Provident Funds Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines applicability to factories engaged in Sch. I industries with 50+ employees; contributions; amended 1960 (50 to 20) and 1962 (rates).

statutes_cited.name: Factories Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Licence issued for premises as one factory.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed confirming High Court's dismissal of writ petition; appellant's factory held to fall under s.1(3) of the Act; no decision on hypothetical contribution rate distinction.
outcome.costs: High Court ordered costs against appellant (implicitly upheld)

key_quotes.text: the word factory used in S. 1(3)(a) has a comprehensive meaning and it includes premises in which any manufacturing process is being carried on as described in the definition
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies broad scope including composite factories.

key_quotes.text: If the factory runs more industries than one all of which are independent of each other and constitute separate and distinct industries, s. 1(3)(a) will apply to the factory even if one or more, but not all, of the industries run by the factory fall under Sch. I.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on applicability to independent industries.
